text:
I always install Tomcat on the C: drive and place my root context files on
another folder.  In the past, I have done this by deleting and recreating the /
context since I was not able to edit it through the administration utility.  On
5.5.9, attempts to do this resulted in the admin utility showing that it was
deleted when it really wasn't.  The only way I was able to get around this was
to create a ROOT.xml file in conf\Catalina\localhost and make my changes there.
 It would seem like either the administration utility should be able to change
the docbase -or- let the user remove/create it.  Also, creating the ROOT.xml
manually seems like a crazy hack that I never expected to actually work.
creator: bryan.mcelhenney@kla-tencor.com

text:
Please try to file bug one can actually understand. Using ROOT.xml is the
expected way: everything else is basically unsupported if you want to redeploy.
creator: remm@apache.org

text:
I got it to work so I'm no longer concerned, but there are still 2 problems:

#1: Admin utility allows you to appearantly delete the '/' context, but it
actually doesn't work.

#2: If editing ROOT.xml is the expected way, then this should be in the
documentation -OR- the file ROOT.xml should already exist in the localhost
folder (it doesn't exist anywhere, nor are there comments that it should be
created).  The /admin context is changed via "admin.xml", the /manager context
is changed via "manager.xml".  So what should the / context be controlled by? 
".xml"?  It's not clearly intuitive that it should be "ROOT.xml" and that the
user has to manually create this to get it to work.
creator: bryan.mcelhenney@kla-tencor.com
remm@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #2)
> The /admin context is changed via "admin.xml", the /manager context
> is changed via "manager.xml".  So what should the / context be controlled by? 
> ".xml"? 

The "/" context by default is nothing special. The other two need the .xml files
to work (they're not even in the host appBase).

creator: bryan.mcelhenney@kla-tencor.com
text:
> The "/" context by default is nothing special. The other two need the .xml files
> to work (they're not even in the host appBase).

I agree, but how does a user who is new to Tomcat 5.x discover how to change the
docbase of / from "ROOT" to "/content/website"?  He/she can't edit the / context
via the admin utility.  Can't delete and recreate it with the changes you want.
   The admin webapp should tell you that you can't delete the / context and
possibly offer a suggestion on the proper way to make your changes.  

Just as important, "ROOT.xml" does not exist and there is also mention of
needing to create it to override the default docbase.

I won't bother you anymore.  It's just that I'm fairly familiar with installing
4.x versions of Tomcat and it took me an hour to figure out how to get this done
and I was hoping to save future users the trouble.  To do this, I'd suggest the
following changes:  

#1:  Allow the admin utility to edit the docbase of the / context (best solution).
-OR-
#2:  Create the ROOT.xml file as part of the install so the user at least has a
hint of where to go.
